Author Full Names: Gaggero, Alberto A.; Piga, Claudio A.
Article Title: Airline competition in the British Isles
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Merger evaluation; Yield management; Inter-temporal pricing
Keywords Plus: PRICE DISPERSION; ENTRY
Abstract: We study the relationship between pricing and market structure on the routes connecting the UK and the Republic of Ireland. Because in 2007 the European Commission prohibited the takeover of Aer Lingus by Ryanair, the analysis focuses on their pricing strategies in particular. We use an original dataset of fares posted on-line, which allows to control for the fares' inter-temporal pattern for each specific flight and each carrier's specific yield management system. Our evidence supports the European Commission's view that the elimination of a competitor in the Irish airline market is likely to have harmful consequences for consumers. (c) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Bayesian inference for vehicle speed and vehicle length using dual-loop detector data
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Bayesian analysis; Dual-loop detector; Vehicle classification; Vehicle length; Vehicle speed
Abstract: A dual-loop detector consists of two connected single-loop detectors placed several feet apart. Compared with a single-loop detector, it is able to provide more useful information on traffic flow with a higher precision. In this paper we investigate statistical inference for vehicle speed and vehicle length using dual-loop detector data. A Bayesian analysis is performed to combine current observations on traffic flow with prior knowledge, which results in a set of simple formulas for the online estimation of both vehicle speed and vehicle length. As a by-product, vehicle classification is also investigated on the basis of posterior classification probabilities. The computational overhead of updating the estimates is kept to a minimum when new information on traffic flow becomes available. The method is illustrated using real traffic data. (C) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Chen, A; Chootinan, P; Recker, W
Author Full Names: Chen, Anthony; Chootinan, Piya; Recker, Will
Article Title: Norm approximation method for handling traffic count inconsistencies in path flow estimator
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Origin-destination estimation; Path flow estimator; Stochastic user equilibrium; Norm approximation; Partial linearization method
Keywords Plus: DESTINATION; QUALITY
Abstract: Path flow estimator (PFE) is a one-stage network observer proposed to estimate path flows and hence origin-destination (O-D) flows from traffic counts in a transportation network. Although PFE does not require traffic counts to be collected on all network links when inferring unmeasured traffic conditions, it does require all available counts to be reasonably consistent. This requirement is difficult to fulfill in practice due to errors inherited in data collection and processing. The original PFE model handles this issue by relaxing the requirement of perfect replication of traffic counts through the specification of error bounds. This method enhances the flexibility of PFE by allowing the incorporation of local knowledge, regarding the traffic conditions and the nature of traffic data, into the estimation process. However, specifying appropriate error bounds for all observed links in real networks turns out to be a difficult and time-consuming task. In addition, improper specification of the error bounds could lead to a biased estimation of total travel demand in the network. This paper therefore proposes the norm approximation method capable of internally handling inconsistent traffic counts in PFE. Specifically, three norm approximation criteria are adopted to formulate three L-p-PFE models for estimating consistent path flows and O-D flows that simultaneously minimize the deviation between the estimated and observed link volumes. A partial linearization algorithm embedded with an iterative balancing scheme and a column generation procedure is developed to solve the three L-p-PFE models. In addition, the proposed L-p-PFE models are illustrated with numerical examples and the characteristics of solutions obtained by these models are discussed. Published by Elsevier Ltd.

Article Title: A heuristic for the train pathing and timetabling problem
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Train; Scheduling; Pathing; Timetabling
Keywords Plus: BUSY COMPLEX STATIONS; FREIGHT RAILROADS; ROUTING TRAINS; SINGLE LINE; MODEL; RAILWAY; TRACK; ALGORITHMS; STRATEGY
Abstract: In a railroad system, train pathing is concerned with the assignment of trains to links and tracks, and train timetabling allocates time slots to trains. These important tasks were traditionally done manually, but there is an increasing move toward automated software based on mathematical models and algorithms. Most published models in the literature either focus on train timetabling only, or are too complicated to solve when facing large instances. In this paper, we present an optimization heuristic that includes both train pathing and train timetabling, and has the ability to solve real-sized instances. This heuristic allows the operation time of trains to depend on the assigned track, and also lets the minimum headway between the trains to depend on the trains' relative status. It generates an initial solution with a simple rule, and then uses a four-step process to derive the solution iteratively. Each iteration starts by altering the order the trains travel between stations, then it assigns the services to the tracks in the stations with a binary integer program, determines the order they pass through the stations with a linear program, and uses another linear program to produce a timetable. After these four steps, the heuristic accepts or rejects the new solution according to a Threshold Accepting rule. By decomposing the original complex problem into four parts, and by attacking each part with simpler neighborhood-search processes or mathematical programs, the heuristic is able to solve realistic instances. When tested with two real-world examples, one from a 159.3 km, 29-station railroad that offers 44 daily services, and another from a 345 km, eight-station high-speed rail with 128 services, the heuristic obtained timetables that are at least as good as real schedules. (c) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: A technical note on Optimizing inventory decisions in a multi-stage multi-customer supply chain
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Inventory; Production; Without derivatives; The perfect squares method
Keywords Plus: ECONOMIC ORDER QUANTITIES; COMPLETE SQUARES METHOD; LOT-SIZE; PRODUCTION SYSTEM; DERIVATIVES; ANALYZE; REWORK; MODEL; EPQ; EOQ
Abstract: We first generalize Khouja [Khouja, M., 2003. Optimizing inventory decisions in a multistage multi-customer supply chain. Transportation Research Part E: Logistics and Transportation Review 39 (3), 193-208] integrated model considering the integer multipliers mechanism and next individually derive the optimal solution to the three- and four-stage model using the perfect squares method, which is a simple algebraic approach so that ordinary readers unfamiliar with differential calculus can understand the optimal solution procedure with ease. We subsequently deduce the optimal expressions for Khouja (2003) and Cardenas-Barron [Cardenas-Barron. L.E., 2007. Optimal inventory decisions in a multistage multi-customer supply chain: a note. Transportation Research Part E: Logistics and Transportation Review 43 (5), 647-654] model, and identify the associated errors in Khouja (2003). We present two numerical examples for illustrative purposes. We finally shed light on some future research by extending or modifying the generalized model. (C) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Chorus, CG; Arentze, TA; Timmermans, HJP
Author Full Names: Chorus, Caspar G.; Arentze, Theo A.; Timmermans, Harry J. P.
Article Title: Traveler compliance with advice: A Bayesian utilitarian perspective
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Advice; Prescriptive information; Guidance; Compliance; Bayesian learning; Expected utility
Keywords Plus: VARIABLE MESSAGE SIGNS; ROUTE GUIDANCE; CHOICE; INFORMATION; TIME; BEHAVIOR; MODEL; DECISION; PROBABILITY; RELIABILITY
Abstract: This paper presents a formal model of traveler compliance with different types of advice (or guidance, prescriptive information) based on the premises of Bayesian expected utility decision-making. The developed model explains a traveler's propensity to comply with received advice in terms of the interaction between his preferences for different travel alternatives, relative importance attached to travel times, perceived travel time uncertainty and perceived unreliability of the information. Following the presentation of the model, we illustrate its workings by means of numerical simulations. (C) 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Dumas, J; Aithnard, F; Soumis, F
Author Full Names: Dumas, Jonathan; Aithnard, Fati; Soumis, Francois
Article Title: Improving the objective function of the fleet assignment problem
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Airline transport optimization; Fleet assignment; Passenger flow; Revenue estimation
Abstract: Most fleet assignment problem (FAP) formulations use a leg-based estimation of revenue loss to derive the passenger revenue component of their objective function. This neglects the leg interdependency of revenues, caused by multileg itineraries. We tackle this problem by modifying the objective function using information provided by a passenger flow model devised by two of the authors. It models spill and recapture between itineraries, accounts for the leg interdependency of revenues and does not control passenger flow to the airline company's advantage. We iteratively improve the FAP's objective function by alternately generating fleet assignments and analyzing them with a modified version of the passenger flow model. We have tested this process on a large-scale network made up of Air Canada data with various demand levels and distributions. Most of the profit improvement occurs in the first few iterations, and the objective function adjustment takes on average less than half the FAP resolution time. (C) 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: On-line calibration of behavior parameters for behavior-consistent route guidance
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: On-line calibration; Real-time route guidance; Behavior parameters; Behavior consistency; Fuzzy control; Deployment
Keywords Plus: REAL-TIME INFORMATION; MODELS
Abstract: This paper calibrates on-line the parameters of a controller-estimated driver behavior model used in a deployable behavior-consistent approach for real-time route guidance by checking the consistency between the time-dependent actual and estimated system states. The behavior model has a fuzzy multinomial logit structure where the systematic utility component is obtained using aggregate behavioral if-then rules. The weights of these rules are calibrated through a fuzzy on-line calibration model using the unfolding traffic volume measurements, The on-line calibration is done within the deployment framework of the behavior-consistent approach where the drivers' likely response is factored in determining the route guidance strategies. The generalized structure of the calibration component enables it to simultaneously incorporate other sources of state inconsistency Such as traffic flow model parameters. The results indicate that the calibration model can enhance the accuracy of system state estimation, leading to the increased effectiveness of the behavior-consistent route guidance. It provides the ability to more accurately predict drivers' likely route choices by using aggregate if-then rules, and consequently, aggregate level data. This is attractive in a deployment context as it implies reduced data needs at a disaggregate level, a difficult proposition in the real world. (C) 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Author Full Names: Arentze, Theo A.; Timmermans, Harry J. P.
Article Title: A need-based model of multi-day, multi-person activity generation
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Travel demand; Activity generation; Time allocation; Task-allocation; Needs; Dynamic micro-simulation
Abstract: In this paper, we develop a model of activity generation for a multi-day planning period that takes within-household interactions between individuals into account. The model is based on the theoretical framework we proposed in earlier work which assumes that utilities of activities are a dynamic function of needs of individuals at person and household levels. In the model, individuals use a utility-of-time threshold parameter to decide when to include an activity in their agenda. The threshold represents a personal perception of time pressure and is continuously adapted based on learning. In an exchange phase, the individuals (re-)allocate household tasks based on a negotiation protocol with the aim of improving the group result. The model takes into account day-varying time-budgets of individuals, influences of perception, selfishness-altruism, joint activity participation and competences of individuals to satisfy particular needs. We illustrate the model by means of simulations and suggest ways for future research. (c) 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: COMPLEXITY IN REFURBISHMENT OF SERVICES SYSTEM FOR HISTORICAL BUILDINGS IN MALAYSIA
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Refurbishment; Building Services; Historical Building; Malaysia
Abstract: Building refurbishment is an important sector in the Malaysian construction industry. High demand for refurbishment projects mainly contributed by increase the number of building renovation, extension and extensive repair works. However, refurbishment projects are difficult to manage compared to new-built projects. This due to uncertainty factors, which are inherent in the projects. The uncertainty of refurbishment project is reflected in the difficulty of getting design information during the design process. As a result, most of refurbishment project end up with high cost and time variances. Therefore, the main objectives of this paper are to present the factors that contribute to the uncertainty in refurbishment of services system for historical building and show how they affect the overall performance of refurbishment projects. Triangulation technique is used for research methodology, which consists of review of literature, semi-structured interviews with 15 architects and postal questionnaire survey that involved 234 respondents. From 234 questionnaires sent out, 82 questionnaires found to be suitable to form a database for analysis. Descriptive and inferential statistics are used in data analysis. The result concludes that refurbishment of services system for historical buildings is complex and difficult in which variables availability of design information, ease of access to building and client's needs were affect performance of the projects.

Article Title: Setting up the Alarm Model of Real Estate Market in Jilin Province according to Dynamic Measure Economics Model
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6

Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: real estate cycle; alarm system; index system; dynamic model
Abstract: On the ground of the theory of economics cycle theory, the article applies dynamic measure economics model to setting up the alarm model of real estate market in Jilin Province, which is related to the development of real estate market in Jilin Province. And it will stimulate the experiential model by selecting the economic datum from 1998 to 2008 at the same time. In the end, it puts forward very important method and own advice to the development of the study. The article only discusses the development cycle of real estate, the real estate cycle can be described as: the reappearance of unequal fluctuation of the real estate income, it leads or lag of the other index. By using dynamic measure economic model to set up real estate alarm model, it can describe profoundly how those factors influencing real estate influence RD, just as mentioned in the part of economic significance of the model, the coefficient in front of every index has the instruction.

Authors: Bakhtiar, KAB; Shen, LY; Khalid, AGB
Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Author Full Names: Bakhtiar, K. A. B.; Shen, L. Y.; Khalid, A. G. B.
Article Title: Perceptions and Practices of Sustainable Construction: An Empirical Study between Hong Kong and Malaysia
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Sustainable development; Sustainable construction; Hong Kong; Malaysia
Abstract: Sustainable construction is widely discussed among researchers since the late 1980s. On the general level, the aims of sustainable construction are implemented most actively in developed countries in which the construction output is limited. However in developing countries, the construction output is increasing and the aims of sustainable construction regarding economic and social issues are more crucial. Many research works have been conducted in investigating existing methods for promoting sustainable construction. However, little data has been collected on evaluating the effectiveness of these methods particularly between developed and developing countries. The purpose of this article is to report on the sustainable construction perceptions and practices between Hong Kong and Malaysia construction professionals. A pattern of perception (POP) framework for comparison was created. The results indicate that the perceptions and practices between the two countries are different.

Article Title: The Application of Innovative Technology for Improvement of Heat Insulation Performance on the Steel Deck Roofs
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Innovative Technology; Heat Insulation Performance; TRIZ theory
Abstract: The colored steel deck plates are often used on the roof of factory building and the extension of the building. The colored steel deck plates have the advantages of structure safety and short construction time. The metal materials are lack of good performance for heat insulation. The insulating material linings are usually placed on the inner side of the deck roof in order to reduce the room temperature. The air conditioners cause a great energy loading problem. The subjects of energy saving and carbon reduction are so important today that the research for heat insulation improvement of steel deck plates must to begin immediately. The research used the innovative technology of TRIZ theory to explore the new insulating coatings on the colored steel deck roofs. The reflective rate of the steel deck coatings has been raised and the insulating ability has been improved as well. The goal of energy saving was achieved in the research.

Authors: Fagiolo, G; Valente, M; Vriend, NJ
Book Editors: Naimzada, AK; Stefani, S; Torriero, A
Author Full Names: Fagiolo, Giorgio; Valente, Marco; Vriend, Nicolaas J.
Article Title: A Dynamic Model of Segregation in Small-World Networks
Source Title: NETWORKS, TOPOLOGY AND DYNAMICS:THEORY AND APPLICATIONS TO ECONOMICS AND SOCIAL SYSTEMS
Book Series Title: Lecture Notes in Economics and Mathematical Systems
Conference Title: NET Conference 2007
Conference Sponsor: Univ Studi Milano Bicocca, Dipt Metodi Quantitat Sci Econ Aziendali,Univ Cattol Milano, Dipt Discipl Mat, Finanza Mat Econ,Univ Studi Urbino, Ist Sci Econ
Abstract: Schelling [19-22] considered a simple model with individual agents who only care about the types of people living in their own local neighborhood. The spatial structure was represented by a one- or two-dimensional lattice. Schelling showed that an integrated society will generally unravel into a rather segregated one even though no individual agent strictly prefers this. We make some steps to generalize the spatial proximity model to a proximity model of segregation. That is, we examine models with individual agents who interact locally in a range of network structures with topological properties that are different from those of regular lattices. Assuming mild preferences about with whom they interact, we study best-response dynamics in random and regular non-directed graphs as wen as in small-world and scale-free networks. Our main result is that the system attains levels of segregation that are in line with those reached in the lattice-based spatial proximity model. That is, Schelling's original results seem to be robust to the structural properties of the network. In other words, mild proximity preferences coupled with adjustment dynamics can explain segregation not just in regular spatial networks but also in more general social networks.

Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Article Title: Developing a Life-cycle Costing Analysis Model for Sustainable Highway Infrastructure Projects
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: sustainability; infrastructure; highway; hfecycle cost; decision making
Abstract: Because of the significant costs and risks involved, financial viability has long been the crux of issue for many construction projects. For highway infrastructure development with huge capital demand, disturbance to natural environment, and long project durations, providing the optimum balance between sustainability provisions and whole of life financial returns is utmost important. Stakeholders of highway construction, from government agencies, through builders and contractors to users and community groups, tend to place significant foci on the early identification of financial outlook when contemplating these infrastructures. Under the current and imrpving social awareness, they will also need to overcome the traditional imbalance between sustainable measures and project budgets, as it can be idealised by owners wanting to maintain lowest possible development cost, whereas environmental experts and technology innovators may push for ultimately green solutions without due financial considerations. Life Cycle Costing Analysis, or LCCA, has been proven as a valuable tool for decision making in the construction industry. While many models were developed and some were used for transport and infrastructure particularly, they are not capable of handling sustainability related costs such as the expenses incurred by dealing with commuter delays or traffic noise. This research attempts to incorporate key sustainability issues and indicators in highway infrastructure development into considerations for financial obligations and profitability in a life long process of the built facility. Through surveys, it identifies then integrates industry verified cost elements relating to sustainability measures with life-cycle cost analysis (LCCA), to aid the decision making of stakeholders. The research employs questionnaire-surveys, model building, analytical hierarchy process and case study, to focus on sustainability issues for highway construction, then identify, evaluate and process their associated costs. These cost elements are being verified by the stakeholders of highway infrastructure projects before their integration into a LCCA model for adaptation and expansion. The financial decision making process will be modelled in a prototype system as a practical tool for stakeholders to evaluate investment decisions and obtain optimum balance between financial viabilities and sustainability deliverables.

Article Title: The impacts of Infrastructure Investment on the Process of Urbanization
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Infrastructure Investment; Urbanization; Impact
Abstract: This paper reviews and clarifies the definition, classification and features regarding infrastructure investment and urbanization. It attempts to analyze and illustrate the impacts of infrastructure investment on urbanization process, based on the basic study on both infrastructure investment and urbanization process. These impacts and functions include: the impact of infrastructure investment on the congregation effect and hub function of cities, the impact on farmers' entry into cities and increasing of employment, and the function of promoting urbanization process.

Authors: Karaca, F; Anil, I; Alagha, O; Camci, F
Book Editors: Athanasiadis, IN; Mitkas, PA; Rizzoli, AE; Gomez, JM
Author Full Names: Karaca, Ferhat; Anil, Ismail; Alagha, Omar; Camci, Fatih
Article Title: Traffic Related PM Predictor for Besiktas, Turkey
Source Title: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGIES IN ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING
Conference Title: 4th International ICSC Symposium on Information Technologies in Environmental Engineering
Conference Sponsor: ICSC
Author Keywords: air pollution prediction; air quality management; monitoring; fine and coarse particles; inhalable particles
Keywords Plus: NEURAL-NETWORKS; POLLUTION; EMISSIONS
Abstract: The main objective of this study was to develop an Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) based model, which could be used as a tool for the prediction of traffic related PM2.5 and PM 10 emissions. In this purpose, about 70 pairs of daily PM2.5 and PM2.5-10 samples were collected near to a main artery in Besiktas, Istanbul, Turkey. In addition to the PM data, hourly meteorological data, air quality data (CO, SO2, NO, NO2, NOx) and traffic data (traffic counts, speed, and density) were employed in the model. The results obtained from two different Neural Networks namely Forward NN (FFNN) and Radial Basis Function NN (RBFNN) were compared. While FFNN did not give good results due to limited number of data (60% of 70 data points) in high dimensional space (i.e., 14 dimensional space), more robust results were obtained with RBFNN with 72% prediction performance.

Article Title: Study of Organizational Planning for Facilities Management to Multiple Projects Group of Shanghai 2010 Expo China
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Organizational planning; Facilities management; Multiple projects group; Shanghai 2010 Expo China
Abstract: The multiple projects group of Shanghai 2010 Expo China is such a mage complex programme that it gives problems to facilities management in terms of both space and time, which pose serious challenges to the integration capability and persistently effective operation capability of the organization for facilities management. Organizational planning for facilities management is a prior program to the real operation later. It is especially important for the complex multiple projects group such as Shanghai Expo, and the proper organizational planning will do much good to the effective operation of facilities management. According to organization theory and the actual conditions of Shanghai Expo, the paper gives a research to the organizational planning for facilities management. Facilities Management Office is established, the positioning and duty scope are defined, organization structure and management responsibility breakdown of the Office are proposed, and operation modes of the Office in different circumstances are designed. The advises from the research and conclusion of the paper would be directly used for the facilities management of The Bureau of Shanghai World Expo Coordination whose general construction management consult partner is Tongji University.

Article Title: Project Cost Overrun Prediction Model with Real-time Bayesian Analysis
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Cost overrun; Real-time Bayesian analysis; Particle filter; Poisson process
Abstract: Construction cost overrun is a common problem in the construction industry. Many factors, such as weather, productivity, and management quality, may have the impact on the cost increase for the construction projects. This paper proposes a model for predicting cost overrun probability based on the influencing factors. The model used real-time Bayesian algorithm (particle filter) is used to run the simulation. One simulated project and one building construction project in Taiwan are used as case studies of the proposed model and a validation purposes. The results prove that the cost overrun prediction model proposed is useful for decision making. It provides the early warning of cost overruns to the project manager of the construction project.

Article Title: On the Importance of a Steady Real Estate Policy-Based on the Analysis of Game Theory
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Rreal estate policy; Equilibrium analysis; Dynamic game model; Government to rescue the market
Abstract: By applying a dynamic game theory, this paper lodged a new view that the implementary process of estate saving policy is, in fact, a game process between government and public. It pointed out that the government should be careful to make the estate saving policy, a variable policy would lead to a more serious market atmosphere, which is unfavorable to restore the consumers' confidence and to revive the market. By applying the backward induction of the dynamic game theory, this paper also established a game model between steady estate saving policies and unsteady estate saving policies. It got that the government's saving policy should correspond to the external marker environment, that is different environment should be taken to different saving policies, but when the market environment has not been significantly improved, the government should apply some relative stable saving policy, only this can minimize the loss. And the equilibrium result is that the public will maintain a stable investment level,which is the expected result.

Abstract: Aiming at increasingly serious construction rubbish in our urban construction, this article puts forward some policies on realizing rubbish reduction as well as resource regeneration starting with the source of building production and then achieving the goals of the whole process control over enterprise production and city management.

Author Full Names: Lo, Hong K.; Szeto, W. Y.
Article Title: Time-dependent transport network design under cost-recovery
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Time-dependent transport network design
Keywords Plus: RESERVE CAPACITY; ROAD NETWORK; EQUILIBRIUM; MODELS; IMPROVEMENT; STRATEGIES
Abstract: Transport infrastructure projects typically take place over a long time span. They will take a few years to plan and construct, and will last decades into the future. Moreover, revenue collection (from tolls) and investments in infrastructure improvement accrue over time. it is, therefore, crucial to determine the optimal project initiation time, phasing, scaling, toll collection strategies, and financial arrangements over the planning horizon. This paper considers the time dimension in the continuous network design problem and focuses on analyzing the aspect of cost-recovery. We develop a flexible framework under two principles of cost-recovery as a single-level optimization program, solve it through the generalized reduced gradient algorithm, and illustrate through numerical examples three considerations: namely, (i) time-dependent demands and gradual network improvements, (ii) comparison between the two cost-recovery principles, and (iii) spatial equity issues from the perspective of consumer surplus. Moreover, this study proves that Mohring and Harwitz's self-financing result for a single facility in a static framework can be extended to the time-dependent network design problem under the same set of assumptions. Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Article Title: Study on the Basic Idea and Application of Partering Model
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Partnering model; CM-Agency model
Abstract: Harmony project management become a new direction of the development of project management,and Parntering model began to focus attention and adoption. The acceleration of the process of globalization,the rapid development of information technology and other changes of the construction industry bring new opportunities to achieve capital, labor, technology, information and other resources on a global scale. Configuration and restructuring improve resources efficiency,and becomes the premise of sharing resource. The rapid development of information technology, increased information transmission channels, shortened the transmission Line of information, improved the communication efficiency, provided technical environment of sharing resources. At the same time, these changes also form the fact that construction industry is facing new challenges and fierce competition. But,the traditional model can no longer respond to new challenges. This paper first analyzes the definition and core beliefs of the Partnering model. and then compare the advantages, disadvantages and core ideas with other models to highlight the features of Partnering model. Finally,it provide a reference work to the China's attempt through the analysis of application.

Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Article Title: Evaluation and Analysis on the Social Responsibility of the Chinese Real Estate Enterprises during the Global Financial Crisis
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: The real estate enterprise; Social responsibility; Factor analytic method
Abstract: Since 2008, the financial crisis which was caused by subprime loan crisis in American has spreaded to many areas around the world, including China's real estate industry. This paper describes the causes of the financial crisis in the United States, analyzes the responsibility of the real estate industry and the characteristics of China's real estate industry. When the real estate enterprises face the dual pressure from market and their own development, It becomes remarkable how real estate enterprises actively and persistently bear their social responsibility to stakeholders, such as shareholders, employees, consumers, government, community environment, the entironment, and so on. This paper,with Factor Analytic Method and by establishing Multiplication Factorial Analysis Model, with the relevant data of case samples(listed real estate in china), estimates synthetically their social responsibility, and analyses the major factors which affect the social responsibility of real estate enterprises and problems in accordance with the result. It puts forward corresponding countermeasures with a view to harmonious development for real estate enterprises in China.

Book Editors: Athanasiadis, IN; Mitkas, PA; Rizzoli, AE; Gomez, JM
Article Title: Multi-agent-based System Technologies in Environmental Issues
Source Title: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGIES IN ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING
Conference Title: 4th International ICSC Symposium on Information Technologies in Environmental Engineering
Conference Sponsor: ICSC
Author Keywords: multi-agent systems; environmental impact assessment; decision support systems
Keywords Plus: DECISION-SUPPORT-SYSTEM
Abstract: Environmental impact assessment (EIA) is one of the principal indicators for human health evaluation as well as for further issues in occupational medicine, public health and planning. Certain difficulties to evaluate EIA appear due to, on the one hand, the nature of contaminants and health characteristics, and, on the other, the difficulties found in data processing, such as heterogeneity of the information sources, lack of data quality and need to use numerous data mining methods. The application of multi-agent systems (MAS) to EIA helps operating with distributed decentralized information and generating general decisions and solutions. In order to facilitate the workflow of MAS planning and implementation in decision support systems (DSS) applied to EIA, a generalized multi-agent system technology (MAST) is proposed. This workflow is general enough to enable the related MAS to be used in any application area requiring decision making. We demonstrate that by only changing the domain ontology the MAS is easily oriented towards another problem area. The functional organization and the roles executed in the MAS conform to the logical sequence of the data transformation flow, which include information retrieval and fusion, data pre-processing, data mining and modeling, and simulation and decision making.

Authors: Tang, SH; Lu, HM; Mao, XP
Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Author Full Names: Tang, S. H.; Lu, H. M.; Mao, X. P.
Article Title: Empirical Study on the Technological Innovation Capability of the Construction Companies in Jiangsu Province
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Construction Companies; Technological Innovation Capability (TIC); Assessment Index; Empirical Study
Abstract: Technological Innovation Capability (TIC) of the construction companies has direct influence on the development of construction industry. How to scientifically and objectively evaluate the TIC is very important and meaningful for the construction companies to adopt the proper innovation strategies and improve the competition advantages. This paper is aimed to analyze the TIC of construction companies in Jiangsu province and demonstrate a TIC assessment framework. Firstly, a thorough analysis of the characters of TIC in the construction enterprises has been made, and the basic principles of TIC assessment have been proposed. Then, a framework of the index system about the TIC evaluation has been introduced. At last, a questionnaire investigation among the construction enterprises in Jiangsu province has been made and a case study about the TIC measurement in a typical construction company in Nantong, Jiangsu has been demonstrated to certify the validation of the index system about the TIC evaluation.

Authors: Wang, J; Wang, Y; Ding, YB
Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Author Full Names: Wang Jun; Wang Yan; Ding Yubin
Article Title: Evaluation of Residential Design by GIOWA Operator in Multi-Attribute Group Decision-making
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: multi-attribute group decision-making; GIOWA operator; Program evaluation
Abstract: In the practice of the real-estate project development, the key of the project's cost-control lies on the early stage of the investment decision and the design phase. Although the design fee takes up 1.5%-5% of building cost in all process of the real-estate development project, but its influence on the control of the cost for construction exceeds 75%. According to a lot of practices, scientific and reasonable design programs can reduce the difficulty of cost-control of the project, which can lower the cost for construction above 10%. Through analyzing and researching the real-estate project appraising in the process of cost-control, based on the GIOWA operator in multi-Attribute group decision-making, A real-estate Project appraisal model is established. And an engineering appraisal example is given to show the feasibility and effectiveness of the model. By using the multi-attribute decision model based on GIOWA operator to evaluate the design program of real-estate, we can satisfy the need of the real-estate enterprises when comprehensive and reasonable assessment is on the way. It can reveal the advantage or disadvantage of each design program correctly and objectively in this way and it has its characteristics of comparison and unity and avoids casualness. So it can provide a scientific and effective quantitative evaluation method.

Article Title: Application of Fuzzy Comprehensive Judgment Method in Evaluation of Risk Value of High-tech Industrialization
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2009 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON PUBLIC ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT (ICPEM 2009), VOL 5: STATISTICS AND METHODOLOGY
Conference Title: International Conference on Public Economics and Management (ICPEM2009)

Author Keywords: fuzzy comprehensive judgment method; high technology; risk factor; value evaluation
Abstract: The risk of high-tech industrialization is objective and all-round. It includes systematic risk and nonsystematic risk. We should systematically understand all risk factors and effectively evaluate them. This paper divides the risk of high-tech industrialization into 3 levels and 21 indices through the establishment of risk index system. By means of expert survey, each index is endowed with weighting, and the risk value is quantified through fuzzy comprehensive judgment method.

Abstract: The strategics of medicine logistics in China arc researched in this paper Firstly, the difficulties confronting the medicine logistics enterprises were introduced Secondly, the strategies of medicine logistics were studied Thirdly, the conclusions were drawn. According to this paper, in order to develop medicine logistics, the medicine logistics markets should be reconstructed and cultivated And the medicine logistics enterprises should take the long-term development suggestions They should raise their logistics integration to the enterprise strategy management, separate the delivery service from the main business service, and develop the countryside distribution system In additional, more and more medicine logistics talented person should be raised in the educational institutions

Article Title: The Global Financial Crisis: Causes, Contagion and Caution to China
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2009 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON PUBLIC ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT ICPEM 2009, VOL 9: SOCIAL SCIENCE METHODOLOGY
Conference Title: International Conference on Public Economics and Management (ICPEM2009)
Conference Sponsor: Xiamen Univ, Sch Econ,Econ Res Journal, Editorial Dept,World Acad Union,Minist Finance, Res Inst Fiscal Sci,Chinese Acad Social Sci, Inst Finance & Trade Econ,San Francisco State Univ, Coll Behav & Social Sci
Author Keywords: financial crisis; subprime mortgage; international currency system; hot money; transmission channels; caution to China
Abstract: The financial crisis that began in 2007 has created the greatest financial dislocations since the Great Depression of the 1930s Inducement of the crisis is subprime mortgage, added to the weakness of international currency system and attack of hot money, the crisis has been transmitted to many fields and regions in the world by the channels of trade, finance and the psychology of investors and so on. China should take the lessons of the U.S as a caution, and enhance financial regulation, take precautions against excessive financial innovation, set up a robust credit investigation system and establish a warning system of financial risk, which will guarantee the health and stability of China's financial market.

Authors: Zhang, YN; Wang, SW; Ma, YM
Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Author Full Names: Zhang Yun-ning; Wang Shuwen; Ma Yuming
Article Title: Gaming Analysis on Rent-seeking or Supervision during Public-Private Partnership Project Legal Person Bidding
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: Public-private partnership; Project legal person bidding; Rent-seeking supervision; Game model
Abstract: For a long time, social commonweal projects and infrastructure constructions in our country depend mainly on government investment, while construction schedules of these projects are difficult to satisfy the demand of economic and social development. The Creation of project finance patterns of public-private partnership, which solves the fund contradiction between supply and demand and attracts social capital widely, paves the way for operation mechanism of whole process management. But the expected return of project and the public interests are all influenced by rent-seeking during public-private partnership project legal person bidding. Commencing on rent-seeking and game between government and bidding operator, this paper constructs a game model of rent-seeking supervision, then analyzes the causes of rent-seeking and supervision countermeasures, hoping to provide evidence for the whole process project legal person bidding supervision of public-private partnership. On the development way of Public-Private Partnership Project Legal Person, the supervision departments will shoulder heavy responsibilities.

Authors: Zhou, ZP; Wang, PP; Li, QM; Deng, XP
Book Editors: Li, QM; Yang, J; Yam, MCH; Deng, XP
Author Full Names: Zhou Zhipeng; Wang Panpan; Li Qimming; Deng Xiaopeng
Article Title: The research on Near-Miss in the construction of metro project based on Knowledge Management
Source Title: CRIOCM2009: INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON ADVANCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND REAL ESTATE, VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Symposium on Advancement of Construction Management and Real Estate
Conference Sponsor: Chinese Res Inst Construct Management,SE Univ, Sch Civil Engn,China Real Estate Assoc,Architectural Soc China, Construct Econ Sub Soc
Author Keywords: metro construction; safety management; Near-Miss; Knowledge Management(KM); Near-Miss Knowledge Management System(NMKMS)
Abstract: Safety management of metro construction has been concerned ceaselessly by researchers and managers. Some achievements have been gained, which has promoted the ability of safety management in metro construction. Nevertheless, accidents of metro project have happened constantly, which indicates that the issues of safety management still harass metro construction. Many investigation reports of metro projects accidents showed that the occurrence of these accidents was not casual without any precursors. Prior to the occurrence of metro project accidents, there appeared many minor incidents without any injuries and loss, and even some safety information unperceived, which is called Near-Miss. At present, the way of safety management based on accidents omits Near-Miss, which is passive and cannot solve the safety problems of metro construction substantially. Moreover, the number of metro project accidents is not enough for researchers to implement quantitative analysis. Hence, research on Near-Miss becomes necessary and important, which would be the key instrument to further safety management level of metro construction. Considering Near-Miss from the angle of knowledge, it belongs to failure knowledge in safety management of metro construction. Therefore, Knowledge Management was applied in the research on Near-Miss. This paper mainly studied Near-Miss from angle of Knowledge Management and founded a Near-Miss Knowledge Management System(NIVIKMS) for safety management of metro construction. Firstly, Near-Miss definition of metro construction was studied. And in the basis of safety pyramid model, comparison between Near-Miss and accidents was implemented. Secondly, conception of Knowledge Management was introduced. And Near-Miss was studied from angle of Knowledge Management. Thirdly, existing Near-Miss Management Systems(NMMS) in the industry of aviation, petrochemical, medical, etc., were analyzed. Based on the process of Knowledge Management, combined with the characteristics of metro construction, Near-Miss Knowledge Management System(NMKMS) for safety management of metro construction was founded from 8 stages: discovery, report, identification, prioritization, cause analysis, solution, dissemination and evaluation. Then, there was an empirical study by implementation the whole course of NMKMS for preventing accidents. Finally, a guarantee system for implementation of NMKMS was proposed from three aspects of implementation body, surveillance body and research body.

Article Title: Multi-class percentile user equilibrium with flow-dependent stochasticity
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Percentile user equilibrium; Traffic assignment; Variational inequality; Convolution; Flow-dependent stochasticity
Keywords Plus: TRAFFIC ASSIGNMENT MODEL; NETWORK; RELIABILITY
Abstract: Travelers often reserve a buffer time for trips sensitive to arrival time in order to hedge against the uncertainties in a transportation system. To model the effects of such behavior, travelers are assumed to choose routes to minimize the percentile travel time, i.e. the travel time budget that ensures their preferred probability of on-time arrival: in doing so, they drive the system to a percentile user equilibrium (UE), which can be viewed as an extension of the classic Wardrop equilibrium. The stochasticity in the supply of transportation are incorporated by modeling the service flow rate of each road segment as a random variable. Such stochasticity is flow-dependent in the sense that the probability density functions of these random variables, from which the distribution of link travel time are constructed, are specified endogenously with flow-dependent parameters. The percentile route travel time, obtained by directly convolving the link travel time distributions in this paper, is not available in closed form in general and has to be numerically evaluated. To reveal their structural properties, percentile UE solutions are examined in special cases and verified with numerical results. For the general multi-class percentile UE traffic assignment problem, a variational inequality formulation is given and solved using a route-based algorithm. The algorithm makes use of the diagonal elements in the Jacobian of percentile route travel time, which is approximated through recursive convolution. Preliminary numerical experiments indicate that the algorithm is able to achieve highly precise equilibrium solutions. (C) 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

In particular, he convinced me that the service flow rate is a better term than capacity for the purpose of this study. At his suggestion, the current manuscript explicitly distinguishes the service flow rate, on which the calculation of travel time is supposed to be based, from capacity, which is typically defined as the maximum hourly volume that has a reasonable expectation of occurrence. Comments of an anonymous referee have helped to improve the analytical results presented in Section 5. The research was supported by National Science Foundation under the Award Number CMMI-0928577.

Article Title: Bicycle commuting in Melbourne during the 2000s energy crisis: A semiparametric analysis of intraday volumes
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Cross-price elasticity; Discrete copula model; Generalized mixed models; Mode of transport; Multivariate penalized spline smoothing; Multivariate count data model
Keywords Plus: MODEL SELECTION; AKAIKE INFORMATION; BAYESIAN-APPROACH; REGRESSION; DISTRIBUTIONS; POLICIES
Abstract: Cycling is attracting renewed attention as a mode of transport in western urban environments, yet the determinants of usage are poorly understood. In this paper we investigate some of these using intraday bicycle volumes collected via induction loops located at ten bike paths in the city of Melbourne, Australia, between December 2005 and June 2008. The data are hourly counts at each location, with temporal and spatial disaggregation allowing for the impact of meteorology to be measured accurately for the first time. Moreover, during this period petrol prices varied dramatically and the data also provide a unique opportunity to assess the cross-price elasticity of demand for cycling. Over-dispersed Poisson regression models are used to model volumes at each location and at each hour of the day. Seasonality and the impact of weather conditions are modelled as semiparametric and estimated using recently developed multivariate penalized spline methodology. Unlike previous studies that use aggregate data, the empirical results show a substantial meteorological and seasonal component to usage. They also suggest there was substitution into cycling as a mode of transport in response to increases in petrol prices, particularly during peak commuting periods and by commuters originating in wealthy and inner city neighbourhoods. Last, we extend the approach to a multivariate longitudinal count data model using a Gaussian copula estimated by Bayesian data augmentation. We find first order serial dependence in the hourly volumes and a 'return trip' effect in daily bicycle commutes. (C) 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Bae, SH; Sarkis, J; Yoo, CS
Author Full Names: Bae, Sang Hoo; Sarkis, Joseph; Yoo, Chung Sik
Article Title: Greening transportation fleets: Insights from a two-stage game theoretic model
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Transportation fleet management; Environmental; Game theory; Regulatory policy; Investment justification
Abstract: The greening of organizational transportation fleets, especially trucks and automobiles, has gained increasing attention by companies in a variety of industrial sectors. The reasons for this concern and attention are due to regulatory and competitive pressures, but also increasing costs of fossil-fuels. Surprisingly the amount of research and modeling for fleet management overall has been rather limited, with the focus on managing green vehicle investments virtually non-existent. In this study we develop a two-stage game theoretic model that helps evaluate, from both policy and organizational perspectives, the implications of greening of transportation fleets. Various parameters are evaluated including factors such as innovations in green vehicle technology, levels of service differences, cost of fuel, adjusting tax policy, regulatory compliance requirements, and adaptation costs. This evaluation provides practical insights into actions that could be considered by regulators and organizations to encourage environmental investments. (C) 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Evidence of convective instability in congested traffic flow: A systematic. empirical and theoretical investigation
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Spatiotemporal dynamics; Traffic database; Traffic flow oscillations; Growth rate; Convective instability; Analytical results
Keywords Plus: BEHAVIORAL-THEORY; REACTION-TIME; MODELS; STABILITY; DIAGRAM; STATES; WAVES
Abstract: An extended open system such as traffic flow is said to be convectively unstable if perturbations of the stationary state grow but propagate in only one direction, so they eventually leave the system. By means of data analysis, simulations, and analytical calculations, we give evidence that this concept is relevant for instabilities of congested traffic flow. We analyze detector data from several hundred traffic jams and propose estimates for the linear growth rate, the wavelength, the propagation velocity, and the severity of the associated bottleneck that can be evaluated semi-automatically. Scatter plots of these quantities reveal systematic dependencies. On the theoretical side, we derive, for a wide class of microscopic and macroscopic traffic models, analytical criteria for convective and absolute linear instabilities. Based on the relative positions of the stability limits in the fundamental diagram, we divide these models into five stability classes which uniquely determine the set of possible elementary spatiotemporal patterns in open systems with a bottleneck. Only two classes, both dominated by convective instabilities, are compatible with observations. By means of approximate solutions of convectively unstable systems with sustained localized noise, we show that the observed spatiotemporal phenomena can also be described analytically. The parameters of the analytical expressions can be inferred from observations, and also (analytically) derived from the model equations.. (C) 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Chen, Q; Li, XP; Ouyang, YF
Author Full Names: Chen, Qi; Li, Xiaopeng; Ouyang, Yanfeng
Article Title: Joint inventory-location problem under the risk of probabilistic facility disruptions
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Joint inventory-location problem; Facility location; Disruption; Lagrangian relaxation
Keywords Plus: DESIGN; MODEL; TRANSPORTATION; VEHICLE; ZONES
Abstract: This paper studies a reliable joint inventory-location problem that optimizes facility locations, customer allocations, and inventory management decisions when facilities are subject to disruption risks (e.g., due to natural or man-made hazards). When a facility fails, its customers may be reassigned to other operational facilities in order to avoid the high penalty costs associated with losing service. We propose an integer programming model that minimizes the sum of facility construction costs, expected inventory holding costs and expected customer costs under normal and failure scenarios. We develop a Lagrangian relaxation solution framework for this problem, including a polynomial-time exact algorithm for the relaxed nonlinear subproblems. Numerical experiment results show that this proposed model is capable of providing a near-optimum solution within a short computation time. Managerial insights on the optimal facility deployment, inventory control strategies, and the corresponding cost constitutions are drawn. (C) 2011 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Evaluating advanced quay cranes in container terminals
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Quay crane; Container terminal; Exploratory factor analysis; Fuzzy AHP
Keywords Plus: FUZZY HIERARCHICAL ANALYSIS; SCHEDULING PROBLEM; BRANCH; BERTH
Abstract: Choosing a suitable advanced quay crane (Q/C) is a complex problem for terminal operators because numerous factors must be considered simultaneously. A two-phased method is developed in this study to deal with this problem. The first phase identities the determinants influencing selection of advanced Q/Cs by applying exploratory factor analysis (EFA) and thereby constructs a hierarchical structure. The second phase applies fuzzy analytic hierarchy process (AHP) to compare alternatives in terms of the structure established in the first phase. The case of the newest terminal at Kaohsiung port is studied empirically and the 40-foot twin-lift Q/C is chosen as the most suitable alternative. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: The dilemma between capacity expansions and multi-airport systems: Empirical evidence from the industry's cost function
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Conference Title: 13th World Conference of the Air-Transport-Research-Society
Conference Sponsor: Air Transport Res Soc
Author Keywords: Airports' cost function; Scale economies; Multi-airport system; Stochastic frontier
Abstract: This paper explores the problematic of airport capacity expansions from the perspective of the airport financial management, using the operating costs as the variable of interest. The objective is to provide empirical evidence on the financial advantages of expanding capacity against the operation of multi-airport systems (MAS) under the presence of significant returns to scale in airport operations. This is done by comparing the actual operating costs of the MAS with the predicted costs that correspond to the aggregated level of output and input prices. Predictions are obtained from a multi-output specification of the industry's cost function, estimated with a broad database of international airports. The results indicate the presence of non-exhausted scale economies at the current levels of production. Hence, the atomization of air traffic always increases operating costs at a system level. In the last section, the degree of economic inefficiency of five European MAS is calculated. These results also provide revealing conclusions about the size of the industry's minimum efficient scale. Furthermore, the use of data on American MAS allows us to separate the inefficiency costs derived from the atomization of air traffic from those related to the individual airports inefficient behavior. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Taste heterogeneity and market segmentation in freight shippers' mode choice behaviour
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Freight mode choice; Taste heterogeneity; Discrete choice; Mixed logit; Latent class
Keywords Plus: PREFERENCE HETEROGENEITY; TRANSPORTATION
Abstract: This paper investigates the prevalence of observed and unobserved taste heterogeneity influencing shippers' mode choice behaviour. The study is based on stated preference data collected in Java, Indonesia. The data were analysed using a mixed logit model, capable of accommodating random taste heterogeneity and panel effects associated with stated preference replications. The results indicate the presence of significant levels of taste heterogeneity, only some of which can be accounted for by conventional commodity-type based segmentations. The analysis goes on to apply latent class methods to identify behaviourally homogeneous segments, which also turn out to not depend on commodity types. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Dekker, S; Verhaeghe, R; Wiegmans, B
Author Full Names: Dekker, Sander; Verhaeghe, Robert; Wiegmans, Bait
Article Title: Economically-efficient port expansion strategies: An optimal control approach
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Port expansion; Optimal control; Economic efficiency; Cost-benefit analysis
Keywords Plus: PRIVATIZATION; CAPACITY; MARKET
Abstract: This paper proposes an analytical model with a control approach to obtain an optimal port expansion strategy by balancing investment costs for the port and congestion costs for its users. Starting point is the optimality condition that marginal investment costs should balance marginal benefits. Particularly the scale effect in investment costs is considered; the consequence that the investment will be made in different stages is included in the solution. By relaxing some assumptions in the model, a numerical optimization algorithm is proposed which is applied to show how the approach can be used to deal with a practical expansion problem. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Boysen, N; Fliedner, M; Kellner, M
Author Full Names: Boysen, Nils; Fliedner, Matte; Kellner, Michael
Article Title: Determining fixed crane areas in rail-rail transshipment yards
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Railway systems; Transshipment yards; Container handling; Crane scheduling
Keywords Plus: INTERMODAL TRANSPORT; SCHEDULING PROBLEM; MODELS; TRAINS
Abstract: To enable rapid container transshipment between freight trains in modern rail-rail transshipment yards efficient computerized scheduling procedures are indispensable. This paper proposes a dynamic programming approach, which determines yard areas for gantry cranes, so that the workload is evenly spread among cranes and, thus, train processing is accelerated. In a straightforward simulation of transshipment yard operations, the effect of optimal crane areas vs. equally sized areas is studied, the latter being a common real-world policy. The results indicate a remarkable speed-up of train processing if optimal crane areas are applied. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Gelareh, S; Nickel, S; Pisinger, D
Author Full Names: Gelareh, Shahin; Nickel, Stefan; Pisinger, David
Article Title: Liner shipping hub network design in a competitive environment
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Hub-and-spoke network design; Liner shipping; Competition; Mixed integer programming; Lagrangian relaxation; Enumeration
Keywords Plus: SPOKE NETWORK; LOCATION
Abstract: A mixed integer programming formulation is proposed for hub-and-spoke network design in a competitive environment. It addresses the competition between a newcomer liner service provider and an existing dominating operator, both operating on hub-and-spoke networks. The newcomer company maximizes its market share which depends on the service time and transportation cost by locating a predefined number of hubs at candidate ports and designing its network. While general-purpose solvers do not solve instances of even small size, an accelerated Lagrangian method combined with a primal heuristic obtains promising bounds. Our computational experiments on real instances of practical size indicate superiority of our approach. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Hou, J; Zeng, AZ; Zhao, LD
Author Full Names: Hou, Jing; Zeng, Amy Z.; Zhao, Lindu
Article Title: Coordination with a backup supplier through buy-back contract under supply disruption
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Buy-back contract; Supply uncertainty; Demand uncertainty; Supply disruption; Decision-making under risk; Non-linear optimization
Keywords Plus: RETURNS POLICY; SINGLE; CHAIN; IMPACT; RISKS
Abstract: This paper studies a buy-back contract between a buyer and a backup supplier when the buyer's main supplier experiences disruptions. The expected profit functions and the optimal decisions of the contract players are derived through a sequential optimization process. The common properties of the contract as well as the differences under the demand uncertainty and the main supplier's recurrent supply uncertainty are explored through comparative studies and numerical examples. The study contributes to the literature by providing a better understanding of the impacts of demand and supply uncertainties and by shedding insights on the value of a backup supply. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: The competition game on hub network design
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Hub-and-spoke network; Game theory; Cournot-Nash equilibrium; Less-than-truckload freight services
Keywords Plus: LOCATION PROBLEM; SPOKE NETWORKS; EXPRESS; FORMULATIONS; MODELS
Abstract: In a competitive market, carriers in network industries design their hub networks and operations plans to maximize their respective profits. The long-term Cournot-Nash equilibrium steady state requires that none of the carriers may unilaterally alternate their hub networks or operations plans to increase profits. We study an integral-constrained game theoretic model for time-definite less-than-truckload freight services in an oligopolistic market. The research showed that carriers favor geographic central than outlying hub locations. With price-elastic demand in the freight market, the higher the network density is, the higher the profit is. Thus, the stable Cournot-Nash equilibrium solution states that all carriers respectively possess a similarly dense hub network, which is robust even with uneven changes in carrier cost structures. However, there is a prorogation effect in that an operating cost reduction will increase the individual carrier's and also the competitors' profits. The results also showed that there are cooperative equilibria that can make all carriers better off, but are unstable solutions in the non-cooperative game. (C) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Author Full Names: So, Stella K.; Daganzo, Carlos F.
Article Title: Managing evacuation routes
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: InFO; Innermost first out; Evacuations; Dynamic evacuation strategies; Adaptive traffic control; User equilibrium
Keywords Plus: CELL TRANSMISSION MODEL
Abstract: This paper shows that evacuation routes, such as a building's stairwell or an urban freeway, may discharge inefficiently if left unmanaged, and that setting priority rules can speed up egress. Therefore, a simple control strategy is proposed. The strategy is decentralized and adaptive, based on readily available real-time data. The strategy is shown to be optimal in two senses: (i) it evacuates the maximum number of people at all times, and (ii) it finishes the evacuation in the least possible time. In both cases, it favors the people most at risk. The results shed light on other traffic problems. (C) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: The impact of truck arrival information on container terminal rehandling
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Container terminal; Container rehandle; Truck arrival sequence; Heuristic algorithm
Keywords Plus: OPERATIONS
Abstract: This paper uses simulation to evaluate the use of truck arrival information to reduce container rehandles during the import container retrieval process by improving terminal operations. A variety of scenarios with different levels of truck information and various container bay configurations are modeled to explore how the information quality and bay configuration affect the magnitude of benefit. The results demonstrate that a complete arrival sequence is not required to substantially reduce rehandles, significant benefit can be obtained under small amounts of information, the benefits grow with the bay size, and that updating information in real time significantly lowers information requirements. Article Title: Equilibrium analysis of macroscopic traffic oscillations
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART B-METHODOLOGICAL
Author Keywords: Traffic oscillations; Wardrop equilibrium; Boston traffic equilibrium; Freeway bottlenecks
Keywords Plus: CELL TRANSMISSION MODEL; BEHAVIORAL-THEORY; FLOW; STABILITY; CLUSTERS; DYNAMICS
Abstract: Using a simple network model with two parallel links connecting a diverge and a merge, this paper studies under what conditions traffic oscillations may be initiated and propagated in a traffic stream, specially at freeway bottlenecks. Drivers are assumed to minimize either the experienced or instantaneous travel times. and in doing so, they settle at a Wardrop (day-to-day) equilibrium or a Boston (within-day) traffic equilibrium, respectively. We prove that the path travel time function in our model is not monotone, and show that this property leads to multiple Wardrop equilibria, of which only one is both stable and efficient. The paper shows that periodic traffic oscillations do not arise from Wardrop equilibria. Trivial oscillations exist at Boston equilibria, which are caused by drivers' overreaction to traffic conditions. However, periodic oscillations are likely to emerge when (1) transitions between stable and unstable equilibria take place, and more importantly, (2) drivers make decisions based on out-of-date information of traffic conditions. The latter finding is useful in guiding control practice at freeway bottlenecks and work zones to prevent traffic oscillations. (C) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Recovery of Rare Earth and Cobalt from Co-based Magnetic Scraps
Source Title: REGULATORY REGIONAL ECONOMIC CHALLENGE FOR MINING, INVESTMENT, ENVIRONMENT AND WORK SAFETY
Conference Title: International Symposium on Project Management
Conference Sponsor: Xi'an Univ Architecture & Technol,Wuhan Univ Technol, Jiangsu Campus,Suqian Econom & Business Collage
Author Keywords: cobalt-based magnetic scrap; cobalt; rare earth
Abstract: The reuse of RE and cobalt in Co-based magnetic scraps was studied. Making sure feat lixiviated condition is that: 200 mesh, sulfuric acid dosage of 1.4 times theoretic dosage, temperature 90 C, leaching time 1 h. The result indicated that lixiviate rate of cobalt and rare earth attained 97.8%, 99.6% respectively. The optimum technology conditions was:Na2S2O8 dosage of 8 times theoretic dosage, oxidation temperature 80 C, oxidation time 2 hour, pH=4.5.Rare earth was precipitated by saturated (NH4)(2)C2O4 solution, after roasting of rare earth oxalate, received rare earth oxide. The samarium and gadolinium sum recovery was 96%, 92% respectively. Cobalt-iron residue was soaked by hydrochloric acid, the Fe(OH)3 was preferential solution, pH was adjusted to 1.4 by hydrochloric acid, Co(OH)(3) does not dissolved, Cobalt and iron were separated, after roasting of Co(OH)(3), received cobalt oxide. The total recovery of cobalt was found to be 97% and rare earths was 96%.

Article Title: Price volatility in the airline markets
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Dynamic pricing; Revenue management; Competition; Price volatility
Keywords Plus: MODELS; DISPERSION; KNOWLEDGE; LATITUDE; SEARCH
Abstract: In this article we examine volatility measures and investigate what factors explain price volatility in different US domestic air routes. We find that volatility remains reasonably stable up to 2 weeks prior to the flight, at which point it increases significantly. The type, LCC or legacy carrier, and identity of the airlines appears to have a major impact oil the volatility measures, and that these effects are different for 2 weeks out and I day out, even after controlling for market differences. Authors: Wan, X; Zou, L; Dresner, M
Author Full Names: Wan, Xiang; Zou, Li; Dresner, Martin
Article Title: Assessing the price effects of airline alliances on parallel routes
Source Title: TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH PART E-LOGISTICS AND TRANSPORTATION REVIEW
Author Keywords: Alliances; Airlines; Competitive strategy; Pricing
Keywords Plus: FARES; MARKETS; WELFARE
Abstract: The impact of airline alliances on airfares on nonstop hub-to-hub routes is investigated. Analytical results suggest that the net effect on airfares is uncertain. Empirical evidence shows that the impact of two of three alliances (Star and SkyTeam) on prices on transatlantic hub-to-hub routes is insignificant after controlling for other factors. Routes between oneworld alliance hubs, however, have significantly lower business class airfares compared to other routes. These results indicate that the impact of alliances on transatlantic hub-to-hub airfares varies depending on the alliance; possibly due to the ability of an alliance to coordinate fares. (C) 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
